text.headline: Origins of Portus
text.text: Portus has its origins in Rome’s need for a large and capacious harbour. The early colony of Ostia was not well-suited to large scale maritime traffic. So, under the later Roman Republic maritime traffic, particularly from the east, arrived at Puteoli (Pozzuoli) on the Bay of Naples, before being transported up the coast and through Ostia to Rome. This rather complex situation was not well suited to the increasingly large volume of supplies needed by Rome from Augustus onwards.

media.caption: Map of Italy showing the location of Portus, 30 km west of Rome

text.headline: The Claudian Period
text.text: The life of Portus itself began in the mid first century AD. It was established 3km to the north of Ostia by the Emperor Claudius by c. AD 46 and was subsequently inaugurated under Nero in AD 64. It comprised of a substantial 200 hectare harbour basin which was connected to the Tiber by two large canals, and by a significant complex close to the Tiber. The canals enabled cargoes from ships arriving at Portus to be moved upriver to Rome in boats. The canals may also have been intended to help prevent flooding in Rome by easing swollen waters in the lower Tiber. Little is known about the infrastructure of the port apart from some very large buildings in the vicinity of the small basin (Darsena), and the supply of fresh water by an aqueduct. On the north side of the Isola Sacra, a small settlement also developed adjacent to the Imperial marble yards in the later 1<sup>st</sup> century AD.

text.headline: Pharos
text.text:
The western extent of Portus was marked by a large lighthouse built by the Emperor Claudius in the mid 1st century AD that imitated the great Pharos at Alexandria. It symbolised Roman power in the Mediterranean. The Pharos stood at the entrance to the Claudian Basin and provided the first of several navigational points that helped guide ships in and then within the complex as a whole.

The Roman writers Pliny the Elder and Suetonius tell us how the large ship that had transported from Egypt to Rome the great obelisk that now stands in front of St. Peter’s Cathredral in Rome, was filled with concrete and sunk in order to provide the solid foundation upon which to build the lighthouse.

media.caption: Depiction of the Pharos at Portus in a mosaic found at Ostia

text.headline: Claudian Basin
text.text:
The Claudian Basin was a large 200 Ha artificial outer harbour basin defined by an estuarine landscape to the east, concrete quays to the north and south and a lighthouse to the west. The principal entrance was from the west, with a secondary in its north-eastern corner.

An inscription from AD 46 found at the site in 1836 commemorates the Emperor Claudius as having delivered the City (of Rome) from the dangers of flooding through the construction of canals (fossis). These stretched from the Tiber to the sea. The inscription also commemorates the construction of the harbour. Here is the full text:

TI(berius) CLAVDIVS DRVSI F(ilius) CAESAR
AVG(ustus) GERMANICVS PONTIF(ex) MAX(imus)
TRIB(unicia) POTEST(ate) VI CO(n)S(ul) DESIGN(atus) IIII IMP(erator) XII P(ater) P(atriae)
FOSSIS DVCTIS A TIBERI OPERIS PORTV[s]
CAVSSA EMISSISQVE IN MARE VRBEM
INVNDATIONIS PERICYLO LIBERAVIT

The northern quay of the Claudian basin was uncovered during clearance work for the building of Fiumucino International Airport in the 1960s. It was built from opus caementicium (hydraulic concrete) and can be traced for well over a kilometre from a point just west of the northern point of the eastern quay (where there was a narrow entrance) as far as the main runway of the airport, but continued onwards to a point a short distance to the north of the Pharos. There is good evidence for a number of structural phases in the surviving concrete.

media.caption: View to the north of Portus where the Claudian basin would have been located. It lies immediately to the south of the international airport of Leonardo da Vinci at Fiumicino.

text.headline: Monte Arena
text.text: Monte Arena is a large and enigmatic sandy prominence that lay on the northern quay of the Claudian basin. It disappeared during the later 19<sup>th</sup>/earlier 20<sup>th</sup> century AD.

media.caption: Remains of a section of the northern mole, near Monte Arena, running in a south-west direction

text.headline: Northern Entrance (to Claudian Basin)
text.text: Geo-archaeological coring has identified a possible entrance in the north-eastern side of the Claudian basin close to the intersection of the northern and eastern quays.

media.caption: Satellite image over the possible location of the northern entrance to the Claudian basin (<i>the open ground at the top of the image<i/>)

text.headline: Port Building
text.text: This building is situated to the north-east of the basin and was built in the second century AD. The building was excavated in the 1960s.

media.caption: Port building adjacent to the Northern Entrance of the Claudian Basin

text.headline: Monte Giulio
text.text: This area lies immediately behind the eastern quay of the Claudian basin. It is the location of a number of large rectangular buildings interpreted as warehouses, baths and a water cistern. Although the latter has been excavated, nothing is known about its chronology.

media.caption: Facade of the water cistern behind Monte Giulio

text.headline: Claudian Quay
text.text: In 2007 the Portus Project team found this large concrete quay that defined the southern edge of the Claudian basin

media.caption: The remains of the Claudian quay which lies beneath the later Palazzo Imperiale. It helped define the southern side of the Claudian basin.

text.headline: Antemurale
text.text:
The Claudian basin as a whole was oriented from south-west to north-east along an axis that focused upon the road (the Via Favia) that linked Portus and Ostia, and which emphasizes the close functional relationship between the two ports. This alignment is shared by a long quay on the eastern side of the southern half of the basin, which probably had its origins in the Claudian period and which continued in use until the end of the life of the port.

This quay defined the western side of the Portico di Claudio, which provided access to two major warehouse complexes, the Grandi Magazzini di Traiano and the so-called Foro Olitorio. Recent excavations have uncovered complex series of buildings along the quay. It is very likely that a small lighthouse was constructed at the northern end of this mole to help guide ships in and out of the Canale di Imbocco al Porto di Traiano.

Antemurale effectively translates as “sea wall” or “bulwark”. The term probably refers here to the defensive wall that occupied the southern portion of the quay from the late 5th century AD onwards.

media.caption: View of a surviving part of the Antemurale close to the lighthouse at its northern end

text.headline: Portico di Claudio
text.text:
This monumental colonnade was constructed in the mid-1st century AD. Being sited on the western facade of the port it would have afforded fabulous views over the Claudian Basin, and provided a monumental façade to ships arriving at the port.

Each column in the Portico is composed of drums of travertine (a type of limestone), with a base diameter of c. 1.05 – 1.26 m and a total height of c. 6 m. The capitals and bases of each column are finished but the drums comprising the shafts have an intentional rusticated (rough) finish. Similar columns can be seen on some public buildings of Claudian date at Rome.

The Portico di Claudio forms a T-junction with a contemporaneous colonnaded route running east-west between the Grandi Magazzini warehouses to the north and the Foro Olitorio complex to the south. This is c. 8 m wide and can be traced eastward almost as far as the Canale di Comunicazione Traverso.

media.caption: View of the surviving colonnaded route of the Portico di Claudio, looking eastwards

text.headline: Molo della Lanterna
text.text: A long concrete quay ran from west to east, acting as the northern side of a channel that provided passage for ships heading towards the Trajanic basin. It was surmounted by a small lighthouse or “lantern” and some baths.

media.caption: View of a surviving section of the Molo della Lanterna, a quay that separates the Darsena and the Claudian basin

text.headline: Darsena
text.text:
The Darsena was a small harbour basin or dock that lay at the heart of the Claudian port. Its function is not entirely clear but it seems likely to have been the anchorage of river boats. These would have been loaded with grain from the adjacent Grandi Magazzini di Traiano and the Foro Olitorio warehouses, and would have then moved by canal and the Tiber up to Rome.

The Darsena connected with the Canale di Comunicazione Traverso – literally the transverse communication channel – which ran southwards from the pool of the harbour. It provided access to the entrance to the Darsena and the Fiumicino Canal.

media.caption: View of the entrance to the Darsena

text.headline: Commercial Buildings
text.text:
Excavations by Lidia Paroli and Mauro Maiorano in the area to the east of the transverse canal, next to the colonnaded road, show that prior to c. the 4th to early 5th centuries AD, the site was occupied by a road junction, on to which opened several buildings of a possibly commercial character. These underwent a continual process of development in the course of the 1st, 2nd and 3rd centuries AD with the appearance of mosaic floors and painted walls.

The position of the buildings would have been perfectly suited to mercantile activities, with the intersection of the canal, the end of the adjacent Darsena, and presumably also both the road leading south towards the Isola Sacra and Ostia. Elements of these buildings were later incorporated into the Basilica Portuense, or early Christian church.

One assumes that one or more bridges may have spanned the Canale Trasverso between this area and the buildings lying to the west of it; since the only representation of these, however, dates from the 16th century, there is no scientific basis for them yet.

Immediately to the west of the Canale Trasverso lie a number of structures that are only known to us from geophysical survey. Further to the west of these, to the east of the Portico di Claudio and to the south of the Darsena, lie the remains of a massive rectangular warehouse complex with central courtyard. This was first identified by Rdolfo Lanciani in 1868, who curiously labelled it as the “Foro Olitorio”.

media.caption: Excavations undertaken here within from the 1990s onwards uncovered a long stratigraphic sequence that begins in c the mid 1<sup>st</sup> c AD and continued down until the 13<sup>th</sup> c. Levels of the 1<sup>st</sup>, 2<sup>nd</sup> and 3<sup>rd</sup> centuries AD revealed buildings with mosaic floors and painted walls, structures that would have been perfectly suited to mercantile activities, as in nearby Ostia.

text.headline: Mausoleum
text.text: This structure was a monumental tomb belonging to a high status individual. It was located in a funerary landscape that lay in the flat land lying between the Trajanic basin and the Tiber.

text.headline: Claudian Aqueduct
text.text: The Claudian aqueduct carried water to Portus from a source in the vicinity of the modern Ponte Galeria (a town c. 10km to the north east of Portus). It ran along the west bank of the river, before turning in a south-westerly direction to head towards the core of the Claudian port in the vicinity of the Commercial Buildings (later the Basilica Portuense).

media.credit: Soprintendenza Speciale per il Colosseo, il Museo Nazionale Romano e l’Area Archeologica di Roma
media.caption: Aerial view of the aqueduct (the dark feature running through the centre of the photograph)

text.headline: Early River Port
text.text:
A series of very large structures have been detected by geophysics and are also visible in aerial photography. These include warehouses and a large residential complex. Since they lay close to the banks of the river Tiber, to the east of the main area of Portus, they are interpreted as a river port.

Further to the south on the opposite side of the Fiumicino Canal lay the Statio Marmorum – the marble yards at Portus, a complex that began to function from the late 1st century AD onwards. In this area our geophysical surveys have revealed some associated structures and tombs overlooking the Tiber.

Between the two lies the Capo Due Rami – the tongue of land at the junction of the Fiumicino Canal and the river Tiber, to the south-east of Portus.

media.credit: Soprintendenza Speciale per il Colosseo, il Museo Nazionale Romano e l’Area Archeologica di Roma
media.caption: Aerial view of the river port. The crop marks outline the remains of buildings

text.headline: Tiber
text.text:
The Tiber, which rose in the Appenines in northern Italy, connected Rome to the Tyrrhenian Sea. It ran through a range of rich lands that produced wood, bricks and other building materials, wine and other agricultural products, both for Rome and, in some measure for export. Movement through the City of Rome was articulated by the river. It was crossed by several major bridges and was bounded by a number of port installations that served downriver and upriver traffic. One of the most important of these was the Emporium. This lay on the east bank was the principal point for unloading cargoes brought upriver from Portus and Ostia.

Major warehouses and other structures like the Porticus Aemilia are known from here, as too a massive hill of amphora sherds from southern Spain and north Africa, known as the Monte Testaccio. The major river port on the west bank was the Ripa Grande. This provided access into the Transtiberim district of Rome, which had a very cosmopolitan character with epigraphic evidence for merchants, and which was directly connected to Portus by means of the Via Campana/Portuensis.

media.caption: View along the river Tiber westwards towards Portus, with the Tyrrhenian sea beyond. The Fiumicino canal can also be seen

text.headline: Roads
text.text:
We know of two roads to the east of Portus. The Via Campana was a major road established in the Roman Republican period. It ran from the Campus Salinarum Romanarum to the north-east of Portus to the Pons Sublicius (the earliest known bridge crossing the Tiber into Rome).

The Via Portuensis was another major road, this time built in the 1st century AD. It diverged from the Via Campana two miles from the centre of Rome, before rejoining it in the vicinity of the modern locality of Ponte Galeria.

The roads are usually referred to simply as Via Campana/Portuensis to avoid confusion. They continued on towards Portus where they diverged just north of Portus’ northern canal, where the Via Portuensis entering Portus from the south-east in the early 2nd century AD.

media.caption: Satellite image showing the excavation of a part of the Via Campana, 4 km north-east of Portus

text.headline: Northern Canal
text.text: The long, irregularly shaped northern canal identified in our geophysics was probably of Claudian date. It ran in a north-westerly direction from the Tiber to the east of Portus, into the Tyrrhenian Sea at a point just to the north of Portus. Its function may have been to alleviate the flood risk in Rome, referred to in the inscription of AD 46.

media.caption: Satellite imagery showing how the remains of the northern canal can be seen through the crop marks

text.headline: Stagno Maccarese
text.text: A salt-water lagoon set back from the coast to the north of the main area of Portus.

text.headline: Campus Salinarum Romanarum
text.text: A flat area of salt pans to the east of Portus that was exploited during the Roman Republican and early Imperial periods.

text.headline: Stagno di Ostia
text.text: A salt-water lagoon lying to the east of Ostia.

text.headline: Isola Sacra
text.text:
One aim of the Portus Project has been to use geophysical survey to gain a better understanding of the Isola Sacra – an artificial island lying between the Tiber, Portus, Ostia and the Tyrrhenian sea.

This was traversed by a road running between Portus and Ostia, and hosted a small settlement in the north with adjacent cemetery to its south. In the early Claudian period there is no evidence for the road preceding the Via Flavia connecting Portus and Ostia, but it is very unlikely that there was no road between the ports. The earliest actual archaeological evidence for the road is a late 1st century AD coin in its make-up.

The geophysical survey has revealed important new details about a major new canal between Portus and Ostia, and the subdivision of the landscape, either for salt pans or for agriculture.

media.caption: View across the Isola Sacra towards Ostia

text.headline: Trastevere Ostiense
text.text: This was a predominately commercial area comprising of massive warehouses and other major buildings on the northern side of the Tiber opposite the main built up area of Ostia. Recent geophysical survey by the Soprintendenza Speciale per il Colosseo, il Museo Nazionale Romano e l’Area Archeologica di Roma and the Portus Project has revealed the layout of some of these and the presence of a major wall to its north, which probably represents the northern extent of the mid 1<sup>st</sup> century BC colony of Ostia.

media.caption: Satellite image overlaid with geophysical results highlight the remains of a number of buildings on the north side of the Tiber

text.headline: Ostia
text.text: Ostia was a major river port lying approximately 16 miles to the south-west of Rome. It was established by the late 4th BC and developed into a major urban community. In tandem with Portus, the Emporium at Rome, and the port of Centumcellae (Civitavecchia), Ostia was a key element in the network of ports serving the capital.

media.caption: Aerial view overlooking the ruins of Ostia with the bank of the Tiber on the far left of the photograph

text.headline: Ostia (Harbour)
text.text: The harbour basin of Ostia was c. 2 Ha in area. Recent geophysical survey and geo-archaeological coring by Goiran and others shows that it originated during the Republican period and was used into the 1<sup>st</sup> century AD.

media.caption: Site of the harbour of Ostia to left of trees at centre of image

text.headline: Roads out of Ostia
text.text:
The Via Ostiense was a major consular road established in the 4th century BC and which ran from Ostia to Rome along the eastern bank of the Tiber.

The Via Severiana was a coastal road that ran from Ostia to Laurentinum and other settlements to the south.

text.headline: End of the Claudian Period
text.text: As we end our visit to Claudian Portus we can reflect on the bustling port whose establishment by Claudius and Nero was to prove fundamentally important to economic and commercial life of the City of Rome.
